title: One Application, Multiple AI Modules
author: Radiant Group
excerpt: Why Radiant chose a modular architecture instead of a single all-in-one intelligence system.
content:
## Context
AI applications often aim for centralized intelligence. In healthcare, this approach creates fragile systems.

## Problem Statement
Healthcare problems are heterogeneous. Imaging, speech, tabular data, and knowledge retrieval have fundamentally different constraints.

## Why Monoliths Fail
Monolithic models are hard to debug, unsafe to update, and difficult to evaluate in isolation.

## Design Principles
- Single responsibility per module
- Explicit interfaces
- Independent evaluation

## System Overview
The application acts as an orchestrator. Each AI module performs one task and returns structured outputs.

## Technical Choices
We separate perception, reasoning, and retrieval rather than fusing them prematurely.

## Evaluation
Modules are evaluated independently using task-specific metrics.

## Limitations
Orchestration adds complexity and requires careful interface design.

## Deployment
Modules can be deployed progressively without disrupting the entire system.

## Lessons Learned
Platforms scale better than products.

## Conclusion
Modular intelligence is not optional for real-world AI systems.
